messageBody:
On Sun, 24 Nov 2002, Bill de hÓra wrote:
> I like the /test/ expansion idea, but... I can't be bothered typing
> this[1] in day in day out:

> [1] package @package

IDEA does this for you automatically for any class.


> import junit.framework.TestCase;
> import junit.framework.TestSuite;
> import junit.textui.TestRunner;
> import java.util.*;
> import java.io.*;
> import com.propylon.test.UnitTestable;

IDEA takes care of all import statements for you automatically too.


> /**
> *
> * @version $Revision: 1.1 $
> * @author <a href="mailto:bill.dehora@...">Bill de hÓra</a>
> */

This too.


> public class @Class
> extends TestCase implements UnitTestable

It types the "public class ClassName" for you; you have to type the rest.


> {
>
> public @Class( String name )
> {
> super(name);
> }

This constructor is no longer required for JUnit. I haven't found any
disadvantage to not using this constructor; does anyone know of one?


> public static void main(String[] args)
> {
> TestRunner.run(suite());
> }

This isn't required with IDEA, because it can run any TestCase you ask it
to even if there is no main() method.


> public static Test suite()
> {
> return new TestSuite(@...);
> }

I never override this method; I assume that it's not necessary (?).


> protected void setUp()
> { }
>
> protected void tearDown()
> { }

I don't use these methods too often, so I wouldn't put them in a template.
When I need them, I hit ctrl-O (for "override method") and IDEA shows me a
list of methods I can override, I pick one or more, and the code is
created.

I am not usually fond of tools that write code for me magically (I think
it could be done better a different way), but IDEA is well enough written
that I trust it to write my code.

Also, anything that IDEA can do, Eclipse can probably do too, and without
the hefty price tag.



Erik
